_header: O death whilom displeasant to nature
_description: An apostrophe of a Lover wishing for Death — one stanza rhyme royal

CamPem307.First Lines:
O dethe whylum dysplesant to natureWhere duellyst þow wylte
                    thou þin man forsake…
CamPem307.Last Lines:
…Cum & helpe the petuys man to endeIn the lythe all here
                    ys non odere ffrende
CamPem307.Note: Added by later hand. adding at the end “At my ending quyt me my mede / & gyue me drynke for my good dede,” followed by four lines from the Confessio (VIII.2837-40), and then DIMEV 6077 immediately after that.

Wilson,  Kenneth George. 
             “Five Fugitive Pieces of Fifteenth-Century Secular Verse.”
